metadata.title: Kinyras
author: John C. Franklin
Glynnis Fawkes
metadata.summary: Whose music did the Trojans groove to before their war with the Greeks began? Kinyras! The king and divine lyre Kinyras anchored a slew of Aegean stories centered on the island of Cyprus, but many were lost over time. In Glynnis Fawkes and John C. Franklin’s witty comic history for this issue’s Not-So-Funny Pages, the musical king returns to center stage—but must share it with that famed pair of star-crossed Greek lovers, Paris and Helen.

content.content: Sing to us of the king, Clio—that musical king and divine lyre—who ruled Cyprus with wealth and song; who died when he lost to Apollo in a musical throwdown.

Glynnis Fawkes and John C. Franklin, pictures and words for “Kinyras,” one of this issue’s selections for our Not-So-Funny Pages section, met on the island of Cyprus. Both were studying the classical and archaeological Greek world, but each did so from their distinctive creative foundations: Fawkes was an artist, and Franklin a musician. Bronze Age sparks flew, and they got together with plans of collaborating on ancient music videos. The music videos haven’t happened yet, though they did get married and have two kids. A veteran of ten years of archaeological excavations in the eastern Mediterranean, Fawkes now [draws witty comics](http://glynnisfawkes.com/), works as an archaeological illustrator, and [paints](http://www.kingmixers.com/AnneGlynnisFawkes/index.html). Franklin is an [Associate Professor of Classics](http://www.uvm.edu/~classics/?Page=franklin.php) at the University of Vermont, an expert on ancient Greek and Near Eastern music, and a [composer](http://www.kingmixers.com/) of scores in the style of ancient Greek music. They live in Burlington.

The following comic is their very first artistic collaboration, though both have worked before on the Cypriot king Kinyras and his place in Greek story cycles. Fawkes’s nine-page comic of the story of [Myrrha and Kinyras](http://glynnisfawkes.com/the-story-of-myrrh) was among the notables of [_Best American Comics 2012_](http://www.hmhbooks.com/hmh/bestamerican/comicsbookdetails), edited by Jessica Abel and Matt Madden. Franklin’s forthcoming book with Oxford University Press, _Kinyras: The Divine Lyre_ is the text on which this comic, or “graphic article,” is based (and also features Fawkes’s illustrations). For this comic, Franklin came up with the script, and Glynnis contributed the art and lettering, adapting and re-imagining scenes to dramatize the text.

Their work is not yet done. Fawkes is planning a larger project in which she’ll expand on the stories of Paris and Helen before they reached Troy; together, they hope to continue the collaboration that began with this piece for _The Appendix_. We can’t wait.

link.label: Franklin’s “The Cyprosyian Girl: Hits of the Ancient Hellenes” is an especially ‘classic’ jam.
